item.title: About
item.description: Hi! I’m a PhD student at Northwestern University focused on parallel and heterogeneous architectures. I work with Professor Nikos Hardavellas under the PARAG@N lab’s Constellation project. I develop novel architectures which leverage explicit parallelism primitives in high-level languages to facilitate faster and more energy-efficient massively-parallel computation. I also attended Northwestern for my Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering, for which I was advised by Russell Joseph and in which I focused on computer architecture and microcontroller systems.

item.title: Projects
item.description: VELMA: Vector Element Load Melding Accelerator When vectorized loads are performed via indirect addressing, particularly as scatter/gather operations, significant spatial locality is overlooked. Consider the case in which two elements in a vector many, many indices apart, are each within the same cache line in memory. Why perform a load on that cache line twice while satisfying one vectorized load? VELMA aims to accelerate vectorized scatter/gathers by melding–or packing–the vectorized loads, while preserving program semantics and ordering.
